posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: I’ve been looking into robot code simulation for a while now, and I keep hearing that I should use Synthesis.  However, whenever I try Synthesis or look at the documentation all I see is a very simple robot builder with physics and (very minor) controller customization.  No code simulator, no hardware replicas, and none of the things I am looking for.  I have seen some vague comments about WPILib WebSockets being changed recently and Synthesis being broken as a result, but I’ve been struggling to get a straight answer.  So, can Synthesis be used for simulating code?  If so, where is this feature?  If not, what are the issues and is there any way I can help find a solution. Thanks for any help you can give

posts.name: Rishi Rao
posts.cooked: I’d recommend looking into AdvantageScope. It’s pretty much the new standard for simulation and it’s included w/ WPILib.

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked: Just to clarify: AdvantageScope is a data visualizer , not a physics simulator. It relies on the robot code to run any relevant physics simulators ( docs ) and handle the required data injection/abstraction to interface with the rest of the code. The robot code then publishes data via NetworkTables , which AdvantageScope (and other tools) can visualize.

link_counts.title: Physics Simulation with WPILib — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Rishi Rao
posts.cooked: Right, thanks for clarifying. The WPILib physics sim classes work very well and pair nicely with AdvantageScope — you just need to publish poses from the code to visualize the mechanisms!
I believe synthesis went through a complete rewrite just a year or 2 ago, so they’re still working to implement a lot of features

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Thanks, that’s helpful.  We’ve tried and failed to integrate AdvantageKit in the past, but it definitely seems worth it so I want to give it another go.  The thing is, AdvantageKit works by completely restructuring your code so you can substitute in input and output objects and rerun inputs from matches, etc.  That’s still very useful, but an ideal simulator would replace the HAL, and wouldn’t require you to change your code at all.  I’ve seen small demos of this from past years, but is there any way to do it now?

posts.name: Steven Pearson
posts.cooked:
Just to be clear, AdvantageKit and AdvantageScope are not the same thing. AdvantageKit requires rewriting your code for inputs and outputs in a specific way. AdvantageScope is a data visualizer that works with things you are probably already logging to NetworkTables (or could easily log).

That doesn’t help you with drop in simulation you are hoping for.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: That’s true.  I am aware that AdvantageScope can be used without AdvantageKit, but I haven’t found that many instances where doing so is useful.  They may crop up—-AdvantageScope and AdvantageKit are both amazing services.  I’m still looking for a real hardware simulation tool though.  If one doesn’t exist, does anyone have recommendations on how to build one?  Does WebSockets still work?  How would you intercept calls to the HAL?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: As far as I know, one does not exist.  The HAL simulation WebSockets interface has existed for several years and would work well for interfacing to WPILib simulation. allwpilib/simulation/halsim_ws_core/doc/hardware_ws_api.md at main · wpilibsuite/allwpilib · GitHub

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Thanks for this resource!  Do you have any suggestions for getting started integrating this feature and using the WebSockets api for a simulator?  What would I need to do on the code side and simulator side?  I realize this is an obscure feature so easy examples probably don’t exist, but any guidance would be appreciated.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
Just a note that terminology wise, this can get a bit confusing, as we call running the robot code on the desktop “simulation”, e.g. “simulation HAL”, “HAL simulation extensions”, etc.

The robot program on the desktop can be configured (via build.gradle) to load either the WS client or WS server HAL simulation extension (or both).  Once a WS connection is established to the robot program, any code updates to HAL values result in a WS message being sent by the robot program, and the other side of the connection can update HAL values, which will then be seen by the code when the code reads from the HAL.

To set up a WS server, add the following to build.gradle:

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Thanks so much!  Do you know of an easy way to view the websockets connection and see the messages?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: There are web browser extensions which let you do test WebSocket connections, but the volume of data generated by the HAL is quite high, so you’d probably be better off with a simple Python client, e.g. Examples — websocket-client 1.8.0 documentation

Would a program using the HAL simulation WebSockets interface act as a replacement for the default simulation GUI, with all the physics still being done by the robot code? Or would the program run its own physics simulation?

Edit: I suppose I’m asking, what is the purpose of a program that connects to the websockets interface

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Either one is possible, but the concept being talked about in this thread would be to still use the robot side sim GUI, and for the non-robot side of the WS connection to be a physics model (so that wouldn’t be in the robot code).

So for the case being talked about in this thread, the program is taking the outputs from the code (like motor voltages), using them for physics sim, then updating the inputs sent to the code (like encoder values)?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Exactly.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: My idea with this is that it could solve the problem of testing hardware-specific code.  With the right code structuring, you can test abstracted command and subsystem logic, but you can’t test interactions with the rio, motors, etc.  This would allow you to test all of that without any code changes.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
Sure.  Just to be clear, you can also test all of that by writing simulation-only physics code in the robot program (simPeriodic is not executed during normal robot operation on a real robot).

Note the external application will need to provide a way to map the hardware I/O to the physics model; e.g. what shaft is driven by what motor (or if you map it directly to a wheel, the gear ratio), what shaft is measured by what encoder, things like encoder counts per revolution, etc.

posts.name: system
posts.cooked: This topic was automatically closed 365 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
